abstract: Tells the delegate that the scene is about to begin running in the foreground and become visible to the user.
overview:
## Discussion

To use this method, you must implement the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UISceneDelegate] protocol and configure scenes for your app (see [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/specifying-the-scenes-your-app-supports]).

UIKit calls this method before moving a scene to the foreground. This transition occurs both for newly created and connected scenes, as well as for scenes that were running in the background and were brought to the foreground by the system or a user action. A scene enters the foreground as a precursor to becoming visible onscreen, so this method is invariably followed by a call to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UISceneDelegate/sceneDidBecomeActive(_:)] method.

In addition to calling this method, UIKit posts a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIScene/didActivateNotification] and a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIScene/willEnterForegroundNotification].

For more information on what to do when your app is about to enter the foreground, see [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/preparing-your-ui-to-run-in-the-foreground].

# sceneWillEnterForeground(_:)

**Instance Method**

Tells the delegate that the scene is about to begin running in the foreground and become visible to the user.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor optional func sceneWillEnterForeground(_ scene: UIScene)
```

## Parameters

- **scene**: The scene that is about to enter the foreground.

## Discussion

To use this method, you must implement the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UISceneDelegate] protocol and configure scenes for your app (see [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/specifying-the-scenes-your-app-supports]).

UIKit calls this method before moving a scene to the foreground. This transition occurs both for newly created and connected scenes, as well as for scenes that were running in the background and were brought to the foreground by the system or a user action. A scene enters the foreground as a precursor to becoming visible onscreen, so this method is invariably followed by a call to the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UISceneDelegate/sceneDidBecomeActive(_:)] method.

In addition to calling this method, UIKit posts a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIScene/didActivateNotification] and a [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIScene/willEnterForegroundNotification].

For more information on what to do when your app is about to enter the foreground, see [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/preparing-your-ui-to-run-in-the-foreground].



## Transitioning to the foreground

- **sceneDidBecomeActive(_:)**: Tells the delegate that the scene became active and is now responding to user events.
